definition[0]: to pull something heavy with a continuous steady movement
example[0]: the steam locomotive which hauled the train
example[1]: I hauled the door shut behind me.
example[2]: She hauled her backpack onto her back.
note[0]: haul something off/onto/out of etc something
definition[1]: a large amount of illegal or stolen goods
example[3]: The gang escaped with a haul worth hundreds of pounds.
example[4]: A haul of stolen cars has been seized by police officers.
definition[2]: the amount of fish caught when fishing with a net
definition[3]: if a train or TRUCK hauls goods, it takes them from one place to another
example[5]: The freight train hauled the load of 240 tons with ease.
example[6]: Union Pacific hauls garbage from Seattle to a landfill in eastern Oregon.
definition[4]: to officially make someone go to a senior manager, committee, or court to be judged on something they have done, especially something bad
example[7]: Officials can be hauled before Congressional committees and asked to justify their policies.
note[2]: haul somebody before/in front of somebody/something
example[8]: Bar staff who serve drunk drivers may get hauled up in front of the local judge if those people are later involved in accidents.
definition[5]: to speak to someone angrily and severely because they have done something wrong
example[9]: He might be hauled over the coals and forced to resign if his manager did not agree with his actions.
definition[6]: the amount of fish caught in one net or in one period of time
example[10]: Demand for fishing boats depends on estimated sizes of fish hauls.
definition[7]: a large amount of stolen or illegal goods that has been found by the police or CUSTOMS
example[11]: A haul of stolen cars has been seized by police.
definition[8]: connected with long or short journeys by plane
example[13]: KLM earns most of its revenue on long-haul flights.
